intro: Lupinus sellulus var. elatus, commonly known as the tall lupine, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, characterized by its distinctive pod-like fruits and nitrogen-fixing ability. The plant features erect, branching stems with palmately compound leaves composed of several oval-shaped leaflets. Its showy, pea-like flowers are typically blue to purple in color, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Lupinus sellulus var. elatus is often found in open habitats like meadows and disturbed soils, where it plays a role in soil enrichment through its legume properties.
